proposition: Does homeopathy work better than placebo for treating medical conditions?

paradigms.name: Scientific Consensus
paradigms.description: Mainstream scientific and medical consensus based on RCTs, meta-analyses, and mechanistic understanding.
paradigms.ontology: Material, measurable biological and chemical processes
paradigms.epistemology: Empirical observation, RCTs, systematic reviews, falsification

paradigms.name: Integrative Medicine Advocate
paradigms.description: Perspective that values holistic approaches and considers patient-reported outcomes alongside RCTs.
paradigms.epistemology: Clinical experience, patient narratives, holistic assessment
paradigms.axiology: Patient autonomy, whole-person care, therapeutic relationship

paradigms.name: Skeptical Empiricist
paradigms.description: Strictly materialist view that demands mechanistic explanations and rejects implausible claims.
paradigms.ontology: Physical matter and measurable forces only
paradigms.epistemology: Mechanism-first, extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence
paradigms.axiology: Scientific rigor, preventing harm from ineffective treatments

hypotheses.name: OTHER - Unforeseen explanation
hypotheses.description: Some unknown mechanism not captured by the other hypotheses explains homeopathy's observed effects (or lack thereof).

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Homeopathy has specific therapeutic effects
hypotheses.description: Homeopathic remedies have specific therapeutic effects beyond placebo through an as-yet-unknown mechanism (e.g., water memory, quantum effects, nanoparticles).

hypotheses.name: FALSE - No effect beyond placebo
hypotheses.description: Homeopathic remedies have no specific therapeutic effect beyond placebo. Any perceived benefits are due to placebo effect, regression to mean, natural recovery, or concurrent conventional treatment.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Works for some conditions only
hypotheses.description: Homeopathy has specific effects for certain conditions (e.g., allergies, anxiety) but not others. The mechanism may be placebo-enhanced or condition-specific.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Therapeutic ritual effect
hypotheses.description: Homeopathy's effects come not from the remedies themselves but from the extended consultation, individualized attention, and therapeutic relationship - a real but non-specific effect.

hypotheses.name: PARTIAL - Low-dose hormesis
hypotheses.description: Some homeopathic preparations at lower dilutions (not ultra-diluted) may have hormetic effects - beneficial responses to low-dose stressors - but this doesn't apply to standard ultra-diluted preparations.
